metadata.case_name: Nazir Mian, Ram Kirpal Bhagat and Ganga Dayal Shah v. State of Bihar

facts.text: On 13 December, 1961, Inspectors Uma Shankar and Bisuddha Nand Jha and Constable Bishan Singh of Central Excise Department were on checking patrol duty on 330 Down Barauni passenger train proceeding from Barharwa to Pakur in Santhal Parganas, Bihar.
Appellant Nazir Mian was travelling by the train and found in the latrine of one compartment with two bags of cloves weighing about 2 pounds 10 seers. Door was closed; Inspector pushed it open.
Inspector Uma Shankar disclosed identity, asked if duty paid on cloves; Nazir Mian answered in negative. Bags seized and Nazir Mian arrested.

Train started moving; stopped at level crossing after alarm chain pulled. Excise staff got down with Nazir Mian and bags. Nazir Mian rescued by other appellants (Ram Kirpal Bhagat, Ganga Dayal Shah) and others; bags taken away. Scuffle ensued; one Inspector simple injuries, other grievous.

Appellants Nazir Mian, Ram Kirpal Bhagat, Ganga Dayal Shah, Jhaman Mian, Raghunath Prasad Yadav charged under IPC ss. 147, 149, 333, 379; some under 332, 225. Nazir Mian also under Land Customs Act s.7, Sea Customs Act s.167 item 81, Imports & Exports Control Act s.5.

Trial before Assistant Sessions Judge, Dumka: Raghunath acquitted all charges. Appellants and Jhaman convicted under various IPC sections, sentenced concurrently. Nazir acquitted on customs charges due to lack of written complaint under relevant sections.

Appeal to Patna High Court (Criminal Appeal No. 210 of 1966): High Court held Sea Customs Act and Imports Act apply; inspectors officers of customs; arrest/seizure lawful; burden under s.178A on Nazir; convictions upheld but some sentences under s.332 set aside for Nazir and Ganga Dayal.
Pakur railway station 11-12 miles from East Pakistan border. Cloves not grown in India, dutiable under Indian Tariff Act 1934 item 93 column 3 First Schedule, no duty paid, concealed in latrine.
Inspectors Uma Shankar and B.N. Jha: Inspectors of Central Excise and Customs, Preventive and Intelligence Section, jurisdiction Pakur, Dumka, Sahibganj since Jan 1961.

legal_issues.text: Whether Sea Customs Act, 1878 applies to Santhal Parganas, making arrest under s.173 and seizure under s.178 lawful.
Whether Bihar Regulation I of 1951 validly applies Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 to Santhal Parganas within Governor's powers under Fifth Schedule para 5.
Whether Inspectors of Central Excise were Officers of Customs/Land Customs Officers authorised to arrest and seize.
Whether reasonable suspicion existed for arrest under s.173 Sea Customs Act based on facts.
Whether s.178A Sea Customs Act applies absent special notification specifying goods.
Whether Land Customs Act, 1924 and Indian Tariff Act, 1934 apply to Santhal Parganas.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sea Customs Act, 1878, Land Customs Act 1924, Imports and Exports Control Act 1947, Indian Tariff Act 1934 not extended/applicable to Santhal Parganas.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Fifth Schedule para 5; no notification; Santhal Parganas Settlement Regulation 1872

petitioner_arguments.text: s.3(2) Imports and Exports Control Act 1947 deems prohibition only under s.19 Sea Customs Act; other sections like 173,178,178A not attracted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Collector of Customs Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty; s.3(2) Imports Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Bihar Regulation I of 1951 exceeds Governor's powers under Fifth Schedule; power to make regulations does not include power to apply laws; conditional/delegated legislation.
Inspectors not Officers of Customs; no authority under notifications.
No reasonable suspicion for arrest under s.173 Sea Customs Act.
No special notification under s.178A; onus not shifted.

respondent_arguments.text: Sea Customs Act applies via s.3(2) Imports Act deeming all provisions effective; Bihar Regulation I of 1951 valid.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Imports and Exports Control Act s.3(2); Bihar Regulation I 1951; Fifth Schedule para 5

respondent_arguments.text: Inspectors appointed Land Customs Officers and thus Customs Officers via notifications.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sea Customs Act s.6 Notif 69-Cus 1951; Land Customs Act s.3(1) Notif CBR 1 Cus 1958

respondent_arguments.text: Land Customs Act existing law under Art.372; Indian Tariff Act applicable via Santhal Parganas Settlement Regulation Schedule.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.372 Constitution; Santhal Parganas Settlement Regulation 1872

court_reasoning.text: s.3(2) Imports Act deems goods prohibited under s.19 Sea Customs Act and 'all the provisions of that Act shall have effect accordingly'; attracts entire Sea Customs Act, not just s.19.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes mere reference from incorporation; cites Madras Customs case holding s.178A applicable.

court_reasoning.text: Bihar Regulation I 1951 valid; Governor's power under Fifth Schedule para 5(2),(3) plenary for peace/good govt, includes applying laws; not delegated/conditional.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies laws akin to enactment; cites Riel v. Queen on utmost discretion.

court_reasoning.text: Inspectors Central Excise Preventive Intelligence are Land Customs Officers per 1958 notif, hence Customs Officers per s.6 Sea Customs 1951 notif.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Combined effect gives authority despite Land Customs Act not directly applying.

court_reasoning.text: Facts (possession no duty, concealed, dutiable/prohibited, near border, not grown in India) create reasonable suspicion for s.173 arrest.
No special notif under s.178A needed for violation of other provisions; but seized goods removed, moot.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Onus not shifted absent spec notif for those goods.

court_reasoning.text: Land Customs Act not existing law for Scheduled Areas under Art.372; not applied pre/post Constitution except via Governor; Indian Tariff Act applicable via 1872 Regulation Schedule.

holdings.text: Sea Customs Act 1878 applies fully to Santhal Parganas via s.3(2) Imports Act 1947 applied by Bihar Regulation I 1951.
Bihar Regulation I 1951 within Governor's plenary powers under Fifth Schedule para 5.
Central Excise Inspectors Preventive are Customs/Land Customs Officers per notifications.
s.178A onus not applicable absent special notification.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindustan Co-operative Insurance Society Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishes incorporation from mere reference in statutes.
Incorporation writes provisions into new Act as if penned anew.
Governor's regulation power gives utmost discretion for peace/good govt.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty
precedents_cited.relevance: s.23A FERA attracts all Sea Customs Act provisions via s.19 deeming; subsequent amendments apply.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies fully via Imports Act; arrest, seizure, presumption, cognizance.

statutes_cited.name: Land Customs Act, 1924
statutes_cited.relevance: Appoints officers; notifications make excise inspectors Land Customs/Customs Officers.

statutes_cited.name: Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits cloves import; deems prohibited under Sea Customs s.19, attracts all provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Regulation I of 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies Imports Act to Santhal Parganas validly under Fifth Schedule.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Governor's power over Scheduled Areas; existing laws.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges for unlawful assembly, hurt to public servant, theft, resistance to apprehension.

statutes_cited.name: Santhal Parganas Settlement Regulation, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies certain Acts including Tariff Act to area.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court convictions under IPC sections for rescue, assault, theft; held arrest and seizure lawful as inspectors were customs officers, Sea Customs Act applicable via Imports Act and Bihar Regulation; reasonable suspicion established; s.178A onus not shifted but goods removed anyway.

key_quotes.text: "The combined effect of both the notifications is that the Inspectors of Central Excise in the present case were Land Customs Officers and Officers of Customs as a result of the application of the Sea Customs Act, 1878."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "These circumstances indicated a reasonable suspicion and, therefore the Officers were justified in arresting the appellant Nazir Mian under section 173 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Bihar Regulation I of 1951 is a valid piece of legislation emanating from the legislative authority of the Governor in its plenitude of power."
key_quotes.speaker: court
